text.0:
A video shared on Twitter claiming to show Kenya's President Uhuru Kenyatta dancing in a crowd without a face mask in spite of Covid-19 restrictions is :cross_mark: FALSE.

:video_camera: The video is from 2017, well before the pandemic: https://t.co/lhxDXcUiWo
text.1:
A public notice posted on Twitter claiming to be from the Forum for the Restoration of Democracy — Kenya (FORD-Kenya) party is :cross_mark: FALSE.

:magnifying_glass_tilted_right: FORD-Kenya's deputy executive director confirmed that the party did not issue the notice: https://t.co/KkOOssYilA
text.2:
A photo shared on Twitter claiming the governor of Kenya's Kakamega County entered Kisii Stadium for the Mashujaa Day celebrations with two wives is MISLEADING.

:magnifying_glass_tilted_right: Mr Oparanya refuted the claim, saying that the women are county assembly members: https://t.co/3RZQmD7nu0
text.3:
A Facebook post claiming the UN has warned Tanzania’s president against plunging the country into violence is PARTLY FALSE.

:page_facing_up: The statement released called on all key Tanzanian actors to refrain from violence and ensure a free vote: https://t.co/NEjK33Ax4e
